newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: PLDT 9-mth net seen at 4.53 bln pesos.
newsitem.headline: PLDT 9-mth net seen at 4.53 bln pesos.

text.p: Philippine Long Distance Telephone Co (PLDT) is expected to post net profit of 4.53 billion pesos in the first nine months of the year, averages from a poll of five stock brokerages on Wednesday showed.
Last year in the first nine months, PLDT reported net profit of 4.6 billion pesos but that figure was boosted by an extraordinary gain of 1.154 billion pesos.
Compared to last year's profits minus the extraordinary gains, the predictions showed that PLDT would post a 30 percent growth in profits over the same period last year.
The firm's extraordinary gain last year had come from the sale of shares in its cellular phone unit Pilipino Telephone Corp.
In the first six months this year, PLDT which is the country's dominant telecommunications company, reported a net profit of 2.917 billion pesos.

Analysts said the firm's year-old drive to cut costs and become efficient had begun to pay off. PLDT used to be a virtual monopoly until three years ago when the government opened the sector to competition.
To face the growing competition, PLDT began a massive expansion programme and also started cutting costs by measures which included retrenchment of workers.

"The impact of PLDT's cost-cutting measures is taking hold. They have reduced manpower and additional phone lines forming part of its Zero Backlog Program are in place and on schedule," Saturnino Mejia, research head at Guoco Securities, said.

Cilette Liboro, research head at Citisecurities Inc, said that although the 4.28 billion pesos profits will largely come from international calls, domestic calls are starting to account for a substantial portion of PLDT's earnings.

Some 72 percent of the telephone company's revenues for the first three quarters will come from international long distance calls, said Raul Ruiz, vice-president for research at Sun Hung Kai Securities (Philippines) Inc.
The recent reduction in accounting rates, the cost of international calls, from $1.20 per minute to $1 will not create a significant dent in the carrier's revenues, analysts said.
International gateway facility (IGF) operators have a 50-50 revenue sharing scheme with their foreign counterparts and a reduction of the rates will mean lesser revenues.

"Even if accounting rates decline, the volume is bigger as more lines are being installed and so lower rates are offset by greater number of calls," Dick Puig, senior analyst at Peregrine Securities (Phils) Inc said.
Analysts added that competition from other carriers such as ICC Telecoms is not likely to eat into PLDT's market share, at least not in the immediate term.
"There are a lot of start-up companies but how many lines have they connected? At the end of the day, it's still PLDT that people turn to," said Kevin Khoe, analyst at Sapphire Securities.
"Metering will be an exciting development as it will initially bring about a 20 percent jump in revenues," said Alexis Cabel, analyst at Ang Ping & Associates.
Starting next year, PLDT along with other telecom firms are planning to adopt a metering scheme on calls instead of the existing flat rate scheme.
